title: The five best new cars launched at this week's Tokyo Motor Show
text:
The Tokyo Motor Show is the main stage for Japanese car makers to show off their latest new models - and a few quirky concepts they promise to release at a later date.

This year's event has been no different, with a raft of releases, from practical superminis that are favourites among Britons to wacky future machines that are more fun than functional.

Ray Massey has been traipsing the show floor in 2019 and named the five cars making the biggest impressions.

Mazda MX-30

The MX-30 is a concept for now but Mazda says it will be sold in the UK from 2021. It features a set of wide-opening barn doors

Mazda fans can look forward to a new electric car called MX-30 – with wide-opening barn doors - costing just under £30,000 after a £3,500 green subsidy.

Order books for a well-stocked First Edition model open in the UK next Spring with first deliveries in February 2021.

It features a 35.5kW battery and has a range of up to 130 miles – more than enough for the average commute, says Mazda which is on track to sell 40,000 cars in total in the UK this year, including the ever popular two-seater MX-5 sports car.

Mazda UK boss Jeremy Thompson said: ’The electric car segment is growing very rapidly. It’s a silent revolution. And 2020 will be the year it really takes off.’

Suzuki Waku Sport

At the press of a button, the Suzuki Waku Sport extends from a city car to an estate with a big boot

Small car specialists Suzuki have excelled themselves with this quirky transformer car called the Waku Sport.

At the push of a special ‘Waku Waku’ button, the plug-in hybrid City coupe turns itself into an estate as a rear section rises out of the boot to create more storage space.

The cute car takes its name from a Japanese expression that evokes excitement and great delight. In English it loosely translates to ‘Surprise, Surprise.’

The Waku Sport draws inspiration from the 1967 Suzuki Fronte 360 and promises families ‘fun and excitement across generations'.

Suzuki’s Hanare, meanwhile, is described as an ‘autonomous mobile room’ on wheels and is inspired by the 1969 Suzuki Carry.

Honda Jazz

The Honda Jazz is a big favourite among Britons. This is the latest model with a fresher look

Honda’s next generation Jazz supermini – the firm’s top UK seller – will be available only as a two-motor petrol-electric electric hybrids.

Sales in the UK and Europe of the new fourth generation Jazz – sold as the Fit in Japan – begin in the middle of next year.

The new car will concentrate on comfort with new seats and improved visibility thanks to thinner pillars, says the Japanese car-maker.

Honda said: ’The new Jazz will introduce the efficiency benefits and performance of hybrid power to the mass market and accelerate Honda towards achieving its ambition of all its European mainstream models to feature electrified powertrains by 2022.'

It will be the first model in Honda’s European line-up to wear the new ‘e:HEV’ powertrain badging, standing for ‘hybrid electric vehicle’.

A new Crosstar crossover variant features increased ride height, a unique front grille design, water-resistant upholstery and integrated roof rails.

Nissan DayZ Highway Star

Ray Massey pictured with the Nissan DayZ Highway Star Kei car in Tokyo

Home grown in Japan, and rarely exported, are really cute fuel-efficient small engined vehicles called Kei Cars, meaning lightweight.

All of the Japanese car-makers produce them including the Nissan DayZ Highway Star (with which I am pictured) and they come in all manner of weird and wonderful designs – often boxy.

Powered by 660cc motors and loved by youngsters as a first car and drivers of more mature years as a cheap and cheerful runaround, owners pay only half the rate of road tax compared to a conventional car. No wonder they account for around a third of annual car sales in the Land of the Rising Sun.

Sadly they rarely come to Britain.

But that may change as Nissan showed off a new electric K-Car called IMk – featuring the new Nissan styling. But bosses say that with electric drive, it’s much smoother and faster than the sometimes huffing and puffing petrol-driven version.

Toyota Yaris

Toyota will bring a new Yaris to the UK, with a hybrid version expected to dominate sales

Toyota has previewed its 2020 Yaris supermini – including a hybrid version – with UK deliveries starting next Autumn.

The rival to the Ford Fiesta and Vauxhall Corsa will come with a hybrid 1.5 litre petrol engine linked to a lithium ion battery pack and a continuously variable - or CVT - transmission.

Customers can also choose a 1.5-litre non-hybrid petrol engine with a six-speed manual or CVT gearbox, or a frugal 1.0-litre three-cylinder petrol.

Tokyo also marked the debut of a new all-electric Toyota LQ prototype hatchback, the second generation Toyota Mirai hydrogen fuelled electric car, and an electric Lexus.
